awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research:  Striving Together? Second-Generation Americans' Path to College
awd_abstract_narration:
We know that there are enduring differences in the rates of educational attainment across different social groups. Because some social groups in the United States have higher levels of college educated adults than others, these adults become an educational and social resource for working-class background youth from these same groups, who subsequently complete more years of schooling than they would otherwise. Thus initial differences in educational attainment are duplicated over time, thus posing challenges to some striving for upward mobility. This project will advance how this process of resource activation unfolds across different social groups. Moreover, the present study will examine whether these resources can be shared beyond the originating social communities to support academic achievement among peers of other social groups through youths? friendship networks.  The study will identify conditions under which high-school level social resources from some groups not only serve to enhance emerging educational mobility strategies of in-group members,  but also advance the social opportunity of working-class students from other social groups through peer networks. Findings will provide guidance for K-12 schools as they strive to encourage higher rates of enrollment in higher education and as well as achievement of post-secondary education among many social groups who are enrolled.  

This project analyzes observational and interview data from 120 high-school aged children of several social groups that vary in terms of average adult educational attainment and in terms of social resources. The project  will interview respondents using a questionnaire and semi-structured interview guide that collect demographic information, college preparation strategies, and access to various forms and origins of social resources. This project will also incorporate similar data from an existing sample of 45 parents and young adults whose help may be useful to high school students striving for upward mobility.  The project will use MaxQDA, which is a qualitative data analysis software that facilitates first and second cycle data coding, to manage, store and analyze all data gathered for this project. The project will also conduct participant observation in several high school settings, including campus sporting events, student free time and during parent-teacher-student organization meetings, to contextualize data produced via questionnaires and interviews.  By understanding what facilitates positive cross-group relationships of adolescents, the study will inform sociological theories regarding social mobility, educational access and  inter-group relations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Social and Economic Sciences

por.por_cntn:
In research made possible by this grant, I investigated variation in the socio-economic mobility pathways used by the children of immigrants in suburban Los Angeles. I relied on four years of observation, 135 surveys and 106 extended interviews with both college-educated and non-college educated Mexican, Salvadoran, Filipino, Iranian, and Armenian immigrant parents and their high school age children to address the effects of selective migration on second-generation outcomes.  Membership in educationally-select, or high-skill immigrant groups, is known to provide access to ethnic capital: those ethnicity-based social resources that support the educational mobility of lower-SES co-ethnics. It is unclear, however, whether ethnic capital ever supports the mobility of non-group members, such as those who attend schools with group members. While past research concludes that membership in educationally select groups sponsors youth mobility because the resources it supplies, ethnic capital, culturally match with American high schools, the approach I advance problematizes social mobility as cultural matching and instead regards it as a relational process that must be negotiated to be beneficial.

I argue that the immigrant group resources made possible by selective migration contribute to a second-generation advantage in education because they allow youth to negotiate custom pathways to college and therefore optimize the opportunities made possible through public policies that expand access to higher education.  I find that even when State policies are designed to promote equity between families, how students negotiate meanings and social relations will shape whether they will benefit, or not, from these policies. Specifically, based on extended field research in a diverse but underserved high school in suburban Los Angeles, I find lower-SES youth of various high-skill immigrant groups accessed and used ethnic capital through community- versus campus-based social ties that encouraged their use of community college dual-enrolment programs allowing them to earn free undergraduate degree course credits, although the high school stigmatized this practice and led these students to feel excluded from it.  Paradoxically, this stigma disadvantaged academically engaged, lower-SES Latino students who reported greater school belonging because they relied exclusively on campus-based ties for college guidance, which favored enrollment in any, even for-profit, four-year colleges. By guiding evaluation of peers’ college choices, belonging prevents non-dominant resources, like ethnic capital, from benefitting students who rely solely on the high school for guidance and reinforces intergroup inequities.

Contrary to past research, I conclude that school belonging in an underserved context, without supplemental community-based resources, poses risks for subsequent social mobility.  Through this contribution, I encourage scholars of migration, inequality and poverty to appreciate the limitations of rational choice assumptions of decision-making that dominate education policy design so they can leverage this dissertation's key contribution: that intergenerational mobility is simultaneously guided not just by the availability of opportunities, but by the relationships that define them as such.

 


Last Modified: 01/02/2022
Modified by: Oshin Khachikian
